/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
I have just hit issues with ansible openstack and have had to apply this patch to resolve this.

We his the issue in OVH's cloud, where I can apply SGs when creating a VM but they are silently ignored - because in OVH the internal network does not have SG's enabled (disabled by policy).

When the openstack.cloud: module is called a second time (in subsequent runs) it will attempt to modify SGs (trying to add 'default' in) which fails due to the call that  adds SGs not failing silently like the create behaviour.

The only way to handle this is the allow for SG to be null by default.

In the instance of multi-homed server,  with this patch I can define SGs on the port: for external, and have no SGs on the port: for the internal.

I suspect we just want the default delimiter behavior for split. See below

The default is to split on white space AND discard any empty strings in the resultant list. By specifying the space delimiter, this will result in:

osd_ids.split("foo bar  baz") == ['foo', 'bar', '', 'baz']

Furthermore, osd ids *must* be integers so passing "foo bar baz" will cause this action to fail part-way into the adding action, which means more to rollback/recover from. We should probably validate this while looping through to save future headache/challenges.

Coincidentally, I think the osd_id.strip() becomes unnecessary if you use the split() form.

I'm starting to think we may want to give this some other name. When trying to make graphs to monitor updater health, I find myself wanting to see how frequently the ratelimiting is kicking in. Previously, I could look at something like

 sum(skips) / sum(skips|successes|failures)

Now I need to do something more like

 sum(skips|deferrals) / sum(skips|deferrals|successes|failures)

to get a comparable graph, *but* there are these funny spikes when a disk full of asyncs finishes its sweep... and I think I'm double-counting since *these* skips were already deferred.

I think you were actually double-counting *all* the skips. 

Assuming that max_deferred_elements > 0 then every update that is rate-limited is counted as a deferral. In addition, every update that was a deferral but is not eventually sent is counted as a skip. There may be a burst of skips at the end of the cycle when there are updates that have not drained, but there can also be trickle of skips as previous deferrals are evicted from the queue.

The final fate of all updates is one of skip|success|failure.
A subset of updates also get counted as deferrals, and a subset of those as drains.

So a measure of what proportion of updates are ratelimited could be:

  ratelimited = deferrals / (skips+successes+failures) [1]

but this will have distortion w.r.t. real time because skips can burst at the end of cycle.

To get a better real time view we could use:

  ratelimited = deferrals / (deferrals+successes+failures-drains) [2]

Note: drains are subtracted to avoid double-counting: drains are deferrals that have gone on to also be counted as success|failure. Also note that [2] is equivalent to [1] because skips == deferrals - drains.

If we want something simpler we'd need to count the number of updates read from disk, then we could just use:

  ratelimited = deferrals / reads [3]

Separately, a measure of the proportion of updates *not sent* in the current cycle could be:

  skipped = skips / (skips+successes+failures) [4]

which might have bursts at end of cycles.

There is a glitch however, when max_deferred_elements == 0. In this case, we would expect:

  ratelimited == skipped

but deferrals is never incremented so ratelimited is 0 (as defined by [1] above). This inconsistency could be fixed by incrementing deferrals even when the deferred queue is size 0 i.e. "deferrals are immediately skips".
Ack

I still wonder a little if it's worth separating the "deferral queue overflowed" skips (which we expect to be smeared out over time) from the "no time left to drain" skips (which will be inherently bursty).

IDK -- I think what I *really* want is some way to amortize the burst over time, but I don't think there's a reasonable way to *do* that. So I'm trying to make it easy to just *drop* the bursts, then try to find some rationalization for doing so later...

tackerclient/osc/v1/vnflcm/vnflcm.py.message: Could you elaborate why you use triple single quote for the string and change the attribute `usage` because I'm not sure the reason simply? Thanks.

I thought that strings without \n were easier to read than strings with \n.
There is no change in behavior from PatchSet 8.

Dear Ogawa San, usage message of heal cli help was coming wrong. The usage message is created by argument parser based upon the argument passed to it. In heal cli this message was coming wrong. That's why we changed the attribute usage for this particular case. 
We used triple string because when we used double quote string then we needed to give "\n" character. But as per Juso san we should avoid these characters. That's why we used here doc so that "\n" character could be avoided.

I've understood it's a deep-seated and hard to fix issued. It's a problem of `argparse` lib we cannot put a positional arg after args of list (configured as `nargs = '+'`) without using some trick. Unfortunately, `argparse` is wrapped with `command` lib and tacker calls `command`, so we can almost nothing for the issue.

I think your fix of telling the order of args is not enough because it's not clear that `<vnf-instance>` should be before `--vnfc-instance` from the help. It's more preferable to separate options and positional arg with `--` like as following.

```
...
[--vnfc-instance <vnfc-instance-id> [<vnfc-instance-id> ...]]
-- <vnf-instance>
```
It should be better to use `%(prog)s` instead for the convention.
Thanks for your comments. I have included %(prog)s in latest patch.

Sorry for my comment isn't enough. Using `--` is to make it clear which arg is positional and should be given after all other optional args. So, `-- <vnf-instance>` should be at the last in this case.

> Dear Ogawa san, In this cli positional arg <vnf-instance> should be given before optional args. If we give positional arg after optional then it gives error. That is why we have mentioned <vnf-instance> before optional args.

Dear Ogawa san, You are right. I have implemented comment in latest patch.

The point is to separate <vnf-instance> with `--` and it's works on my env as bellow. `myinst` is accepted as vnf instance from the command line although it doesn't exist actually. Please ignore some warnings because of ubuntu package.

```
$ openstack vnflcm heal --vnfc-instance fde3e19f-40a7-4208-9ad9-ae41be1451a2 fde3e19f-40a7-4208-9ad9-ae41be1451a3 -- myinst
/usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py:122: PkgResourcesDeprecationWarning: 0.1.36ubuntu1 is an invalid version and will not be supported in a future release
  warnings.warn(
/usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py:122: PkgResourcesDeprecationWarning: 0.23ubuntu1 is an invalid version and will not be supported in a future release
  warnings.warn(
Can not find requested vnf: myinst
```

Dear Ogawa san, In this cli positional arg <vnf-instance> should be given before optional args. If we give positional arg after optional then it gives error. That is why we have mentioned <vnf-instance> before optional args.

the setup for the nova-libvirt container is really confusing.
there is a bindmount /var/lib/docker/volumes/nova_libvirt_run/_data:/var/run/libvirt
but then there is also one for /run:/run. and since /var/run is a symlink to /run, 
the libvirt data end up in all of these locations.

the good news about this is that the prometheus exporter can work without having 
to change anything about the libvirt container

Hi Vishal, api-ref is correct, it documents how API works (I tested QoS policy creation to be sure :P)
I am on the side to follow what's in the api-ref, but perhaps we can have amotoki's opinion.

To answer Vishal's question on the neutron API, we need to visit the history of QoS support in both neutron and OSC.

First, let's look at the history in neutron. The initial version of QoS minimum bandwidth rule supported 'egress' only (in "qos" extension) and the 'ingress' support was added to neutron later (as "qos-bw-minimum-ingress" extension), so the default value is set to 'egress' to ensure the backward-compatibility for those who use the minimum bandwidth rule. The default value is intentional and the API reference in neutron is correct.

Next, let's look at the history in OSC. When neutron QoS support was implemented in OSC, both of "ingress" and "egress" support of the minimum bandwidth rule were already implemented and --direction option was implemented as required. I think it is natural as both directions are already supported and QoS implementation has no preference over two of these.
(BTW, as a side story, '--direction' for the bandwidth limit is optional and lets neutron decide the default value (i.e "egress". It is because "ingress" support was added later and it needs to be optional to ensure the backward compatibility.)

> IMO we should have the same behavior in CLI and horizon.

There is no strict need that that CLI and API should have the same defaults.
The default values can be decided from different reasons and aspects.

> I also confused when I look at api-ref, maybe networking api-ref is incorrect and needs to be updated.

As explained above, the neutron API reference is correct. I confirmed the neutron API implementation.

This is my understanding on the neutron API and OSC. Hope it helps your understanding.

api-ref/source/parameters.yaml.message:
This is about https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tempest/+/811191, right? I'm not sure that this is the best place to put it, as any use of the `addresses` parameter anywhere in the api-ref will start including this disclaimer, whereas the delay is specific to floating IP assocation, as it has to do with the Neutron -> Nova external event interaction. And even then, the delay is only important for code, not for humans, as normally just the time it takes to type out `server show` on the CLI is enough.

Perhaps include this in `Show Server Details` section? Or in the Neutron api-ref, in the `Update Floating IP` section?

The address basically never guaranteed to be up-to-date in any OpenStack Compute (nova)api API call today, so it can be part of the address field description.

The accepted API contract used to be no-delay.

Adding such wait was hard NO from the formal QA PTL and other cores, 
if I remember correctly he also had TC to agree with this.

BTW, when people were asked, about would they expect delay there if they would be new to openstack and would not know about internals.
Nobody said yes.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
hm this seems familiar w.r.t. the centos 8 EOL. Perhaps a regression?


```
fatal: [aio1]: FAILED! => {"attempts": 5, "changed": false, "msg": "Failed to download metadata for repo 'advanced-virtualization': Cannot download repomd.xml: Cannot download repodata/repomd.xml: All mirrors were tried", "rc": 1, "results": []}
```

This is on an upgrade job, where first the N-1 branch is checkout out, deployed and then the code at current branch is checked out and an upgrade run.

Because the N-1 branch pins the SHA of the ansible roles (in ansible-role-requirements) you don't get the roles checked out to the tip of stable/<N-1>, but whatever the the SHA was on the last stable point-release we made was.

I think that the centos-8 upgrade jobs are broken broken across all of the stable branches at the moment because we have not cut a point release since that time.

See https://review.opendev.org/q/I216e5ba34afaf51ec2b3e7c6460ed45378ef8678

cinder/volume/drivers/lightos.py.message:
This would be a breaking change, since a nova service running old os-brick connector would fail to connect with this new connection information.

Since se haven't actually released os-brick we can just be careful when merging these 2 patches.
Yes, that's the plan, merge these before the next release.

I liked the hostnqn naming better, because within the connection information the nqn would make sense for refer to the storage system, and so to differentiate things we would need to name the one from the connector as hostnqn

I'm OK with leaving it as it is or removing it.

I assumed you were sending it in the connection info to be able to check, in the future, on the os-brick connector that the connection info was created for the specific host.

In other words, in the dsc_connect_volume method in os-brick we could have:

 hostnqn = self.get_hostnqn()
 if hostnqn != connection_info['hostnqn']:
     raise exception.Invalid("nqn in connection info doesn't match this host's")

But that would be a breaking change, since nvmeof already uses 'nqn' to refer to hostnqn in released versions. That's why we went with nqn, although we all agree it would be clearer to distinguish between host and subsys nqn's.

Sorry, I'm missing how my suggestion is a breaking change. We would end up with this:

Connector dictionary:
  nqn => connector nqn (ie: nova's nqn)

Connection dictionary (returned by this method):
  nqn => storage nqn
  hostnqn => hostnqn (ie: nova's nqn)


And actually the proposed renaming from "hostnqn" to "nqn" would be the breaking change.

The fact that something is called nqn in the connector properties doesn't mean that it should have the same name in the connection properties.  In fact, it should be de opposite, since they are looking at things from different perspectives.  The connector info describes the host that is going to connect to the volume, whereas the connection info describes host to connect to the storage.

So if we have key "nqn" in the dictionary that describes how to connect to the storage one would assume that this means that that's the storage's nqn, and would be surprised to realize that it's in fact the connector host's nqn instead.

I understand what you mean, but going over the code, it looks like no one is using it anyway. any use of hostnqn/nqn in the connector is coming from the connector and not the connection properties.

Think its safe to remove it?

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
> A couple of notes on potential simplification for the interface, because it's not clear whether these choices were made as a safety measure or not:

They were not, just for ease of usage
 
> 1. The encrypt_file_recipients could be simply populated with the key IDs from encrypt_file_keys, on the assumption that if you pass public keys to the role those are the ones you want the file(s) encrypted for.

The thinking here is that you have one big list of every possible key defined (in our case, in system-config) and then you pick-and-choose a subset of those keys on a per-job basis (so we'd have a list of "always" keys, and then jobs would .append() specific keys)

> 2. The keyd_id could be inferred from gpg_asc, as it's sort of redundant to supply both.

Would that require writing out the key more though?  Currently we do the quick probe just by doing gpg "--list-keys {{ zj_encrypt_file.key_id }}" and skip writing out the gpg and importing it in that case.  With this model, we'd probably have to write the gpg, get it's id, then probe if it's imported, then remove the file?

> In the static node scenario, is it going to be a problem if the already imported key expires but the role avoids importing the updated version (the key ID doesn't change when you update expirations).

hrm ... maybe?  I guess we can parse "expires" in 

 pub   rsa4096 2010-06-12 [SC] [expires: 2022-06-11]

and run the import path if date > than?  I guess we have till 2022-06-11 to figure that one out 😊

> Patch Set 34:
> It's not entirely clear to me why you'd need to know the IDs of keys you're not going to import

I'm trying to optimise for people calling this who keep a single variable with every possible public key in it in one place, but who wish to encrypt specific files for only a subset of these keys, referenced by "friendly" string name.

I just thought this was overall easier -- keep your big list of keys, and then when you're encrypting files just do

 ... in global var ...

 encrypt_file_keys:
    - name: ianw
      ...
    - name: fungi
      ...
    - name: clarkb
      ...

 ... when you want to encrypt a file ...

 import_role:
  name: encrypt-file
 vars:
  encrypt_file: /path/to/file
  encrypt_file_recipients:
    - ianw
    - fungi
    ...

It is true that we could make the users of the role filter their big-list-of-keys down to just they keys they want to encrypt for.  I just feel like as written, this makes the role really simple to use and quite clear about what file is being encrypted, and to whom. 

> nor why you need to avoid importing keys if you're separately specifying the list of ones to encrypt for anyway.

I am imagining this runs on a static node, so to avoid importing the keys for every user every time (which is pretty heavy, each user takes 3 calls -- import the ascii key, get the fingerprint, update trustdb to say we trust it) it probes to see if the key is there with "gpg --list-keys <keyid>".  So the avoiding importing is just an optimisation for the most usual case that the key is already registered on the static node.  In an ephemeral node, it's much of a muchness as every key will be imported anyway.

I'll take the prior votes on this, because I'd like to get the production jobs working with this.

I believe I have addressed one of fungi's concerns with expiring keys with the follow-on [1]

The other was that this could be simpler if we just passed the keys to use.  I will propose a follow-on that can handle an empty recipients list and just use the passed keys, which I think will address this.  It's not how I've written all the system-config changes to work, but it may be useful for some.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul-jobs/+/829853

I'll submit another patch to change this name as this patch is not an appropriate place to change the name ``instance_id`` to ``stack_id``.  There are many places using this name and changing this name will involve DB migration. Such changes should be separated from this patch.

I just tried to point out the name ``instance_id`` is confusing because it's actually ``stack_id``. The role of this attribute is not clear. When an InstantiatedVnfInfo is created, ``vnf_instance_id`` is ``vnf_instance.id`` [1]. However, it will be overwritten by ``stack_id`` here. 

Also, this value is not defined in SOL003 [2]. Thus, I thought at least the name should be clear.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
I want to hold this until someone has a chance to look at the rbd code.  (But I don't want to hold indefinitely, we need to decide whether we want to use --pool or --dest-pool in Yoga.)

The question here is whether we should use --dest-pool or --pool in creating the statement we send to the rbd CLI.

The response to the bug Sofia filed at Ceph says that --pool isn't mentioned for the 'import' command, but then admits later that yes, it is, because given that the image-spec argument in the form pool/namespace/imagename is not required (though it is preferred), you are allowed to specify each part of the spec individually using the --pool, --namespace, and --image options.  Now when Sofia uses the pacific 'rbd import' using --pool, she is getting the message saying that --pool is deprecated and we should be using --dest-pool instead.

The output of 'rbd help import' for pacific shows that --dest-pool is valid.  The deprecation warning implies that "--pool <pool>" is the same as "--dest-pool <dest-pool>", and when you look to the docs to verify this, the word 'dest-pool' does not appear anywhere on https://docs.ceph.com/en/pacific/man/8/rbd/ ... so there is definitely a doc bug, as Sofia said.  (It looks like the responder got caught up in whether this is specifically an import command problem or not, and completely missed the point that the CLI says --pool is deprecated in favor of --dest-pool, and this appears nowhere in the pacific man page for rbd.)

(I'm dumping that here instead of in the Ceph bug because I don't have a Ceph tracker account, and will not have one for a day or two because of spam problems.)

Anyway ... if --pool is deprecated, it will be removed at some point, so we should start using --dest-pool ... or if that is also going to be deprecated, we need to switch to using the image-spec format of pool/namespace/image.  The primary issue for us is that for Cinder, we claim to support the 2 active releases + the prior 2 releases.  Ceph 17.2.0 (Q) is supposed to be released during march, and the Yoga openstack release is on 30 March.  So the yoga rbd driver code needs to support Q, P, O, and N.  So if --dest-pool is valid back to the Nautilus rbd CLI, I think we should *not* revert this change.
Looks like this is ok to do.
Thanks Sofia, looks good to me.
Yes, the linked ceph bug shows that the rbd import is one of the command which uses --pool instead of --dest-pool...

os_brick/initiator/connectors/base.py.message:
It looks like all the subclasses of BaseLinuxConnector take a 'driver' argument to their __init__() and then pass it on to super().__init__() ... so I think you need to keep this, something like:

  if driver:
      self.set_driver(driver)

That being said, the InitiatorConnector metaclass __init__() also takes a driver argument but doesn't do anything with it.  I wonder whether the driver parameter should be removed from InitiatorConnector.__init__() ... it looks like this was the only subclass that actually did anything with it.  Similarly, instead of calling set_driver() here, we could just remove the driver parameter completely, because I don't think any of the subclasses of BaseLinuxConnector actually use it, either.

I guess what I'm saying is that your patch either goes too far (by completely ignoring the driver parameter) or not far enough (by not removing the driver parameter completely).

The reason for not removing the driver parameter is that it is part of the method signature of connectors and is at least called by nova[1] (and all other driver connector implementations[2]), glance[3], ironic(maybe) and other projects? Removing it seems unsafe if some part of code (legacy) is still passing the driver parameter (even when we aren't doing anything with it) and it will break those projects.
The main aim of this patch is to remove the HostDriver so I do not intent to do any major changes to the brick interface (exposed to other projects) in this patch.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/virt/libvirt/volume/fibrechannel.py#L35
[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/tree/master/nova/virt/libvirt/volume
[3] https://github.com/openstack/glance_store/blob/master/glance_store/_drivers/cinder.py#L755

in ansible role, you can create like below (I have not run it but please modify in case of any syntex error or so):
 https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tacker/+/824948/21/roles/setup-multi-tenant-vim/tasks/main.yaml#8

It create the project/users/assign role with the devstack-admin creds whihc is created in devstack side[1]

 - name: Create the first OpenStack project, user, and assign role.
   shell: |
     openstack --os-cloud devstack-admin project create --domain\
     {{ os_domain_tenant1 }}\
     --description 'First project to Test multi tenant policy' \
     {{ os_project_tenant1 }}
     openstack --os-cloud devstack-admin user create --domain\
     {{ os_domain_tenant1 }}\
     -- password {{ os_password_tenant1 }} {{ os_username_tenant1 }}
     openstack --os-cloud devstack-admin role add --project\
     {{ os_project_tenant1 }}\
     --user {{ os_username_tenant1 }} {{ os_member_role }}

 - name: Create the second OpenStack project, user, and assign role.
   shell: |
     openstack --os-cloud devstack-admin project create --domain\
     {{ os_domain_tenant2 }}\
     --description 'First project to Test multi tenant policy' \
     {{ os_project_tenant2 }}
     openstack --os-cloud devstack-admin user create --domain\
     {{ os_domain_tenant2 }}\
     -- password {{ os_password_tenant2 }} {{ os_username_tenant2 }}
     openstack --os-cloud devstack-admin role add --project\
     {{ os_project_tenant2 }}\
     --user {{ os_username_tenant2 }} {{ os_member_role }}
